bug.short_desc: ProjectContainerView leaving empty Project Container Tabs

long_desc.thetext:
1. Open a ProjectContainer using the ProjectContainerExplorer 2. Close ProjectContainer using ProjectContainerExplorer 3. Click on tab in ProjectContainerView:
Result: Then the name of the tab changes to Project Container and the View is empty.
Desired Result: The tab in the ProjectContainerView should just close when the ProjectContainer is closed.

That is not the case. In fact it was a PCV that from previous Eclipse session. After restarting Eclipse the state of PCV is not recovered (yet).
To check if this is it, do this: 1. Open a PC - a PCV is opened. 2. Switch to an other tab, eg. "Problems" 3. Restart Eclipse. 4. The workspace is recovered, you are again on "Problems" tab, and there is a PCV tab too, but inactive. 5. Click the PCV tab. It turns out that the tab is empty and its name is changed to Project Container View.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 161726 ***

bug.short_desc: Creating a new midlet produces @Override annotations

long_desc.thetext:
Creating a new midlet produces @Override annotations which produces errors to source code editor and to Java perspective's problems view.
Steps to reproduce the bug:
1) Use java 5.0 as default JRE for the eclipse 2) set system wide compiler compliance level to 5.0. 3) Create new MIDlet project using MTJ MIDlet Project wizard and WTK2.2 as a runtime platform. (Don't use Hello_World_MIDP template). 4) Create new MIDlet class using the new Java Class wizard.

The compliance level has to be set to 1.4.
-Arto

I think that this is still a bug because MTJ MIDlet project wizard should not generate code that is not Java ME compliant.
MTJ MIDlet project wizard should change project specific compiler compliance level to 1.4 by default.
or
this features should be documented in user docs.

Here is a little scenario (just to make my point clear).
My friend told me about this new MTJ plugin. I'm really exited about it. I download and install the latest Java SE SDK. Next I download the latest eclipse and the MTJ plugin and install them.
Now I decide to create a new midlet. So I use MTJ MIDlet project wizard to create a new project. Then I create a new MIDlet using a new class wizard (taking into notion that there is no new MIDlet wizard). MIDlet code generates perfectly fine but it has annotations and the views are full of errors.
The first impression is that this MTJ plugin does not work.
I have updated the project create to have project specific compiler compatibility. With this, the JDT will not put 5.0 compatible entries in new source files.
setting correct version.

bug.short_desc: ajc create the bytecode that cause java.lang.VerifyError by instantiation

long_desc.thetext: I'm not sure why you think this would work? There is more to connecting a pair of aspects together than just setting the superclass of one to be the other???? I don't think we support this way of working.

(In reply to comment #1)
why shouldnt it? the both aspects have the same pointcut name; the compiler have the access to the both aspects, i.e. pointcut definition and advice.
where is the mistake in this way?

AspectJ has a number of public, documented (http://www.eclipse.org/aspectj/doc/released/devguide/index.html) interfaces for performing aspect weaving. For example you can use ajc to for compile- or post compile-time (binary) weaving. Alternatively you can use Aj or the -javaagent for load-time weaving.
If you really want to find the differences - put the 'extends' into the source, do a full build and compare the class file resulting for the sub-aspect and your 'faked' sub-aspect.

(In reply to comment #4)
okay the bytecode is not the same, but i compared the compiler's output of TestUnit putting 'extends' to source code with the output provided using "'faked' sub-aspect" this is the method doK (normal): // access flags 1 public doK() : void ATTRIBUTE org.aspectj.weaver.MethodDeclarationLineNumber : unknown GETSTATIC TestUnit.ajc$tjp_0 : JoinPoint$StaticPart ALOAD 0 ALOAD 0 INVOKESTATIC Factory.makeJP(JoinPoint$StaticPart,Object,Object) : JoinPoint ASTORE 1 INVOKESTATIC ConcreteAspect.aspectOf() : ConcreteAspect ALOAD 1 INVOKEVIRTUAL AbstractAspect.ajc$before$asps_AbstractAspect$1$5d3d8e49(JoinPoint) : void L0 (8) LINENUMBER 18 L0 GETSTATIC System.out : PrintStream LDC "TestUnit doK" INVOKEVIRTUAL PrintStream.println(String) : void L1 (12) LINENUMBER 20 L1 RETURN L2 (14) LOCALVARIABLE this TestUnit L0 L2 0 MAXSTACK = 3 MAXLOCALS = 2
and "faked":
// access flags 1 public doK() : void ATTRIBUTE org.aspectj.weaver.MethodDeclarationLineNumber : unknown GETSTATIC TestUnit.ajc$tjp_0 : JoinPoint$StaticPart ALOAD 0 ALOAD 0 INVOKESTATIC Factory.makeJP(JoinPoint$StaticPart,Object,Object) : JoinPoint ASTORE 1 L0 (5) LINENUMBER 18 L0 INVOKESTATIC ConcreteAspect.aspectOf() : ConcreteAspect ALOAD 1 INVOKEVIRTUAL AbstractAspect.ajc$before$asps_AbstractAspect$1$5d3d8e49(JoinPoint) : void L1 (9) GETSTATIC System.out : PrintStream LDC "TestUnit doK" INVOKEVIRTUAL PrintStream.println(String) : void L2 (13) LINENUMBER 20 L2 RETURN L3 (15) LOCALVARIABLE this TestUnit L1 L3 0 MAXSTACK = 3 MAXLOCALS = 2
so i realize they are not the same but can the code in the second case cause the "Incompatible argument to function"-error?

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility package should not be x-internal

long_desc.thetext:
The org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility bundle contains a package org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility that has a PluginActivator class. Old style plugins use this class as their Bundle-Activator class (e.g. see org.eclipse.core.resources). The problem is the compatibility bundle exports the org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility with the x-internal:=true directive.
This will prevent all old style plugins from running if strict-mode is enabled (osgi.resolverMode=strict) because they will not be able to load their own bundle activator class.
I suggest we export the package without x-internal:=true. We cannot rename the package because lots of bundles out there are depending on the package name remaining constant. Like it or not this class really is API that we cannot change in binary incompatible ways.

really? There are people who have PluginActivator listed as their plugin class? Is this inserted by the PluginConverter? I'm not fussed if we change the x-internal setting as this is clearly a backward compatibility bundle. I am also somewhat surprised that there are people who care about running old plugins and running in strict mode. not sure why I am surprised but I am. Are there actual people are is this hypothetical?

We were talking about that with John today and it seems that the reference to PluginActivator is added in manifest by PDE when doing the conversion from 2.1 to 3.0 style plugins. This does not surprise me since PDE is using the same plugin converter than the one used at runtime.

Interesting. not sure what the right answer is here. just removing the x-internal is fine. I'm still curious about people who are trying to run in strict mode...
Side question. If PluginActivator is internal, are there other options for people? Can they just remove this and use something else?

The only option they would have is to copy the code, but instead of doing that they are probably better off just creating a bundle activator of their own (the pluginactivator was bridging the activator lifecycle to the plugin class one).
With respect to running in strict mode, I somehow thought we had decided that running with the backward compatibility layer and the strict mode where antinomic. Therefore I would not change the x-internal clause.
Sidenote: If we believe that strict mode matters, then we should have tests and test suites. I'm happy to open the bug report :)

Yes, I had the same recollection regarding backward compatibility and strict mode. We'll have to see what Tom can come up with for actual use cases...
As for the test cases, sure, you;re happy to open the bug but are you happy to do the work? ;-) Seriously, we should have at least some tests that run in strict mode and we should compile with strict mode. Actualy, I believe we decided to do that some weeks ago. Not sure if that happened. Can you check on that? (since you are volunteering...)

Usecases? ;-)
The reason I opened this defect is because of a conversation I has with John Arthorne. He made me aware that the org.eclipse.core.resources bundle still uses the old-style Plugin-Class manifest header and uses a Bundle-Activator org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility.PluginActivator
I got to thinking that "internal" in the PluginActivator package name is not good and then realize that this bundle will not even start if in "strict" mode because the package is exported with x-internal.
John's motivation to leaving resources as old-style was to exercise the backwards compatibility code. If we ever want org.eclipse.core.resources to run in strict mode then we either need to remove x-internal from the package export or convert the resources bundle to not use the PluginActivator class.
IMHO we should update all of the SDK plugins to use best practices. This reduces confusion in developers who look to our stuff as examples. We can have test cases for testing backwards compatibility.

I think there is at least a tooling issue here. I never even realized (or perhaps I had forgotten) that I was using an x-internal class here. I have both forbidden and discouraged access set to "Error" severity in this project, but I guess the manifest builder doesn't test this. Presumably there are lots of plugins out there that have had this compatibility class inserted in their manifest and have since forgotten it was there.
I have entered bug 162402 to migrate remaining org.eclipse.core plugins off of compatibility

I also just noticed that on the "Overview" tab of org.eclipse.core.resources that it lists the activator as org.eclipse.core.resources.ResourcesPlugin (which is not an implementation of BundleActivator). It looks like the manifest editor is hiding the fact that this compatibility activator is being used.
Mistake in previous comment: ResourcesPlugin does implement BundleActivator because the Plugin superclass does, but it's not listed as the Bundle-Activator in the manifest.mf file.
re comment 11. If it is not listed as the activator then it is not the activator. The notions of activator and "Plugin" ar separate. You can have a Plugin object that is not the activator.

After some experimenting, it looks like if you have org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility in your prereqs, then it will list the plugin class in the "Activator" field on the Overview tab (even if it isn't the Bundle-Activator in the actual manifest file). If you don't have runtime.compatibility as a prereq, it shows the real Bundle-Activator in the "activator" field. This is slightly confusing, but the real problem I'm interested in is seeing a warning or error for my use of the internal class. Note I have released fixes for all plugins that used compatibility so you need to go to a previous version to see the problem.
*** Bug 122547 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

It seems there is nothing to do here if we are ok with the fact that backwards compatbility will not work in strict mode. Core resources has moved off the backwards compatibility code and so no longer relies on this internal class.

bug.short_desc: [hotbug_request] Persisted sql models for Informix 10/Sybase 15 from WTP 1.0.x don't work in WTP 1.5.x

long_desc.thetext:
For sql models created in Informix 10 and Sybase 15 using WTP 1.0.x, the version # string from the vendor docs are "10" and "15".
In WTP 1.5.x, the version # strings are "10.0" and "15.0" which causes problems for models created in WTP 1.0.x (i.e. when acquiring a DatabaseDefinition, etc)

More info using Sybase 15 as an example:
Assume an old offline connection or persisted model for Sybase 15 is loaded/processed in WTP 1.5.x, and we have a Database instance for it. Now when attempting to acquire a DatabaseDefinition for it using org.eclipse.wst.rdb.internal.core.definition.DatabaseDefinitionRegistry.getDefinition(Database database), it returns null since it can't find a db definition for Database instances having "15" as it's version. That is, it can't find the vendor model for it from amongst the various vendor models defined in vendor docs residing in the org.eclipse.wst.rdb.dbdefinition* plugins, because the org.eclipse.wst.rdb.dbdefinition.sybase plugin in WTP 1.5.x defines the version # as "15.0". The WTP 1.0.x version of the org.eclipse.wst.rdb.dbdefinition.sybase plugin defined the version # as "15".
This difference is essentially the problem.

Raising this as a hot bug pending investigation.
Affiliation: IBM Release: 1.5.2 Justification: The RDB team provides additions to WTP in our adopter product that allow db definitions to be persisted in the workspace. Due to the change above this causes workspaces containing db definitions to be incompatible between WTP 1.0.x and WTP 1.5.x. The RDB team is investigating options, including whether it is possible to support both WTP ids internally or migrate db definitions to avoid the incompatibility. If workarounds fail, the change in WTP will need to be reverted.
Created an attachment (id=52715) Defect fix

This is really a regression because in WTP 1.0, we provided support for Informix version "10" and then in WTP 1.5 it was provided as "10.0". The same problem applies to Sybase "15". The patch will make these versions available programmatically but they will not show up in the connection UI which is the intended behavior.

+1 This fix looks simple enough and safe enough.
I was initially a bit concerned that this wasn't serious enough, but, if I am understanding correctly, sometimes the persited data (that needs to be "migrated" from WTP 1.0 to WTP 1.5 involves more than just recreating a connection ... that some adopters can have a rather complex "nest" of data that would all have to be recreated if they can not migrate from 1.0 to 1.5, so ... in short, I do think important enought to fix.
As always, I am concerned this regression was detected so late, though. Can you please provide some "migration" JUnit tests that would catch this sort of thing earlier (that is, please open a bugzilla for yourself so this important area can have some time allocated to it)? This might especially be important when talking about migrating people's saved data states from RDB 1.0 and 1.5 to, eventually, DTP?
Patch applied on October 26th, 2006 to the WTP 1.5.2 branch.

+1
Is this due to any recent changes after 1.5?
The change (committed on May 2nd,2006) that introduced this regression was introduced in WTP 1.5.0.

David, the recently added dbdefinition JUnit tests would have caught this problem had they been in place for WTP 1.0. These tests will also be ported to DTP. Therefore, I don't believe additional testcases are necessary.

+1 for WTP 1.5.2
Looks safe and necessary.
Verified fixed.

bug.short_desc: Report Designer PDF viewer throws an exception

long_desc.thetext: I receive this "org.eclipse.birt.report.service.api.ReportServiceException: Report engine fails to create extension to handle this request" when I run the pdf viewer from eclipse. The preview and html viewer work fine on the report. The report is very simple and I have ensured that I have the itext jar installed in the suggested lib folder. I also tried placing the itext jar in the birt viewer web-inf/lib folder but to no avail. I'm using eclipse 3.2 (build M20060629-1905), the BIRT PDF Emitter shows a version of 2.1.1.v20060926-0959 and everything else in birt that I've tried seems to work fine.
Created an attachment (id=52706) The report design file is attached.

The original error happens within eclipse using the viewer option with the report designer. However, I've now followed the instructions to install the birt viewer in tomcat 5.5 and everything works well EXCEPT when I choose the print button I get the exact same error message.
Please put itext-1.3.jar in eclipse\plugins\com.lowagie.itext_1.3.0.v20060909-0630\lib folder. It worked well for me.

Thanks Jerry. That's exactly where I put the itext jar file but to no avail. I downloaded the itext jar file from from the link at the birt installation page then I tried itext 1.3.1 but that made no difference. What I find interesting is that the web viewer (i.e. the birt web viewer example servlet) also fails in exactly the same way. Each of these fail differently when the itext jar is not present and throw the exception I reported when the itext jar is present which leads me to believe that there is something about the reporting engine configuration that is incorrectly configured.
I can now also see a number of others in the newsgroups who have experienced this exact problem.
This build ( 2.1.1.v20060926-0959 ) has some issues about pdf. Please check the later release. Thanks.
Thanks -- I'll do that and let you know the result.
Can not reproduce in the later build.

bug.short_desc: API addition to Program - to get all application images.

long_desc.thetext:
The current Program.getImageData() only returns a single 16x16 image for an application. There should be an API to get the entire set of images associated with an icon on the platform. Possibly returning an ImageData[]
Windows and Mac platforms support multiple Icons embedded in the application icon. The current Macintosh Implementation already has all of this information, but just extracts out the 16 x 16 image and returns it, when there is a beautiful 128 x 128 icon just waiting there for our use :-(
As we move to higher resolution monitors and better video display in general, this type of information becomes critical to make our application look good :-)
API request, SN to consider
for 3.4 ?

bug.short_desc: Profiling of Server does not show Agent Selection Popup on Linux

long_desc.thetext:
Profiling tomcat server the Agent Selection pop up is not displayed. The user is unable to select the pi agent to start monitoring. This appears to be a problem on Linux based systems. I have seen this problem on both RedHat Enterprise 4 and Suse 10.
There is a work around for Java Profiling collector but there is not one for Instrument Collector. For Java Profiling start the server in profiling mode then do an Attach to java process from the Profile wizard. Then you should see the data collection. For Instrument Collector specfically ARM the probes are never deployed for runtime instrumentation so this solution will not work. Instead the user would have to statical instument the application and do an attach scenerio to the java process.
It is critical that this fixed in 4.3
Matt, I cannot reproduce the problem with Tomcat 5.0.28 and JVM 1.4.2_12-b03 on RHEL 4.0 using TPTP build 20061025 build. (WTP1.5.1/JEM1.2.1/GEF3.2.1/EMF2.2.1)
After testing with build TPTP-4.3.0-200610251507 everything is working fine. I guess build TPTP-4.3.0-200610240100 is bad. I have tested both on SUSE and RHEL and both worked fine.

bug.short_desc: Preview matching lines in Search view

long_desc.thetext:
When I do a global search the Search view is populated with a tree of all of the resources which matched the search. I must now open each resource and examine the matches to determine if they are relevant.
This task could be made simpler and faster if the matching lines were actually displayed in the search view, probably as children of the resources. This would allow me to eliminate many irrelevant matches without opening the resource at all.
Right now search is roughly equivalent to "grep -c" -- it just shows where the matches are:
>grep -c o *.txt foo.txt:2
I'd like it to be more like "grep":
>grep o *.txt foo.txt:Hello foo.txt:World
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 47136 ***

bug.short_desc: JavaScriptContentAssistProcessor leaking because of preference listener

long_desc.thetext:
1. JavaScriptContentAssistProcessor objects leaking source of leak
org.eclipse.wst.javascript.ui.internal.common.contentassist.JavaScriptContentAssistProcessor (#01a4151e) [7] of java.lang.Object[9] (#00623206) listeners of org.eclipse.core.runtime.ListenerList (#01133091) listenerList of org.eclipse.ui.preferences.ScopedPreferenceStore (#00cd8fd2) preferenceStore of org.eclipse.wst.javascript.ui.internal.editor.JSEditorPlugin (#0094a323) instance of org.eclipse.wst.javascript.ui.internal.editor.JSEditorPlugin (#00cea5d5)
Looks like the reason is we're never calling JavaScriptContentAssistProcessor.release()

Created an attachment (id=53931) org.eclipse.wst.javascript.ui.patch
JavascriptContentAssistProcessor.release() needs to be called to release itself as a preference listener. There are 2 cases when this processor is used but not released. When the Javascript editor is using it, and when the html content assist processor is using it in 1 specific case.
To fix the Javascript editor case, I subclassed the base's ContentAssistant and did something similar to StructuredContentAssistant (which is used by all StructuredTextEditors) where it keeps track of processors added and then in uninstall, calls release on the processors if it's possible.

Created an attachment (id=53932) org.eclipse.wst.html.ui.patch
The specific html content assist processor case is a new JavascriptContentAssistProcessor is created in HTMLContentAssistProcessor when it realizes that it's at the end of a </script> tag (the normal case is JavascriptContentAssistProcessor is associated with the script partition and that's all handled correctly by StructuredContentAssistant)
This patch just fixes this 1 specific case so that rather than creating a new JavascriptContentAssistProcessor, there's 1 lazily created per HTMLContentAssistProcessor. And it is properly disposed of in HTMLContentAssistProcessor's release().

I had added the "investigate for 153" status because an adopter had found this leak. Actually, the adopter had found a big leak in the javascript editor (bug 144666) and upon testing, he found that the big leak was fixed, but this small one still existed.
The leak occurs every time the javascript editor is open, but the leak is rather tiny (about 24bytes) so for the sake of wtp 1.5.3 stability, I'm just going to postpone this to wtp 2.0.
fix released for wtp 2.0 m6.
verified in wtp2.0 M6 200704021416

On the first page of the wizard, if I click on Client project to specify client project settings, the created Java project is not in the pulldown list for me to choose. I defined an extension for org.eclipse.jst.ws.consumption.ui.clientRuntimes as below

The Java project will appear in the pulldown list if I change the version of jst.java into 1.3, like the following

However, I specifically need to change the version into 5.0 so please investigate why it doesn't work if the version equals to 5.0. Thanks.

Kathy, please investigate - Thanks, CB.
Sean, is the wizard able to create the project for you if you instead type in something that doesn't exist?

This turns out to be a Eclipse JDT Java core problem where it returns the default compiler compliance setting as 1.4 even though it should be 1.5. The workaround is to explicitely set project specific compiler compliance level rather than relying on checking the default compliance level. I've opened Eclipse JDT bug 171465 for this problem, added Sean to the CC list and asked for it in Eclipse 3.2.2. Please put it on your adopter hot bug request (don't know if you have one for Eclipse) if you need to ensure that it is addressed in Eclipse 3.2.2.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 171465 ***

Created an attachment (id=57432) Patch for jst.consumption
In FacetUtils.getFacetsForJavaProject, use JavaCore.getOption("org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.compliance") instead of JavaCore.getDefaultOption.

(In reply to comment #5) > Patch ready for review and commit. > IMO, it would be better: 1) to use JavaCore.COMPILER_COMPLIANCE constant instead of a literal string 2) remove the unnecessary cast: JavaCore.getOption(String) already returns a String
Then your line would be: jdkComplianceLevel = JavaCore.getOption(JavaCore.COMPILER_COMPLIANCE)

I'll reopen this because it really is a bug.
The problem is a classical string comparison bug in DevicePlatformDirectoryEditor.
Generally when comparing strings for equality you should not use == operator.
The reason why it works on windows is that SWT windows implementation of org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Text getText() method checks the length of the text and if it is 0 then the literal "" is returned which is comparared against "" literal. "" == "" is true
SWT Linux Gtk implementation does not return literal "". Instead it returns new String instance which is compared against literal "". new String("") == "" is false
I'll submit a patch for it...

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Navigator Framework Sorters Need Override Capability

long_desc.thetext:
Hi. Within the Data Tools project, we provide the Data Source Explorer, which is based on the 3.2 Navigator framework. Within this framework, we have many levels at which extenders can provide content (via catalog loaders, custom content providers, etc).
We have run into a situation where sorters associated with a given content extension are not playing well together. For instance, let's say we have two content extensions, each providing different content and sorters for a particular node in the tree.
Content Extension A provides three nodes to a folder in the tree and sorts them alphabetically.
Content Extension B provides three nodes to a folder in the tree and sorts them in reverse alphabetical order.
So you end up with something like this:
Folder A B C Z Y X
We need the ability to override all sorters within a particular level (in this example, the Folder) with a custom sorter. Extenders are asking for the ability to do more than just alpha sort a particular level, as we have investigated overriding the default sorter in the navigator framework to simply alphabetically sort all nodes. That is not an acceptable option.

We are looking for solutions at this point. If the framework can't provide something, we will need to implement our own extension framework for sorting within the Data Source Explorer.
For additional discussion, see BZ entry 150592 for Data Tools.
Thanks for your consideration. --Fitz
cc'ing Rob Cernich (DTP)
Updating summary to add [Common Navigator]
Is this still an issue?

bug.short_desc: after deactivating task, restore editors opened when no task was active

long_desc.thetext:
I had had Mylar installed for a couple days before I did anything with it. At the time, I had quite a few file tabs available for files in my somewhat large project, representing files I've viewed or edited in recent history.
So, I finally opened the task list and created a task (I ended up creating 2), and then re-visiting some files I knew were relevant to those tasks, and setting landmarks in those files.
I then unchecked the radio button for the active task, which I would assume would have taken me out of the active task "mode". After doing that, my middle content area with all of my file tabs was now completely blank. Fortunately, the "File" menu had most of those files in the "recent files list", so I didn't have to dig through my package explorer again.
My original list of open tabs is now gone. I tried restarting the workspace while having no task checked, but they were still gone.

Mylar actively manages your open editors with task context. So when you deactivate a task, all editors will be closed, and then reactivated when you open the task again. It takes some getting used to, but enables switching between tasks when you are multitasking without cluttering your editor tabs. This editor management can be disabled via Preferences -> Mylar -> Context. However, before disabling it consider reading the "Managing open editors" section of the following article: http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-mylar2/index.html
If this feature is still not working as you expect after experimenting further please reopen this bug report.
Rob: could you please add a "Why did all my editor tabs disappear?" entry to the FAQ?
FAQ updated.

I think it's always worth considering "the rule of least surprise". I have 30 file tabs open. I install Mylar. I create a task and activate it. I deactivate it. All of my file tabs are gone. Is that surprising? I'd say so. It's reasonable to assume that if you go into a mode that changes your context, it will restore the previous context when you leave that mode.
I understand if you only ever do work in active tasks, this would never be an issue, but it's entirely possible that not everyone is going to do that.
It is an interesting angle. I agree that does make sense on task deactivation restore all editors opened before tasks was activated. Mylar already does similar thing with filters...

Yup, David's rationale you sounds right to me too. Another related thing is that I would like Mylar to restore the perspective that was active before I activate the task (because I frequently switch back to the Planning perspective with no task active). So as you say Eugene we can consider this to be a part of the restore.
The perspective part from comment#5 is done. The restore of editors will be way easier to do once we have progress on bug 138666, so deferring the rest post 1.0.

bug.short_desc: [context] Allow "Make Landmark" to work anywhere in the file

long_desc.thetext:
When I'm adding files as landmarks, if I just click at the top of the file, above the class declaration, and execute "Make Landmark", it complains that I have to select an element and then make that a landmark.
It seems to me that it would be sensible to automatically find the top-level element and use that, if no element is selected.

i run into this problem alot as well. Often the way i work is that i know several classes that are going to be key to the bug i'm working on, but i'm not yet sure what methods will be relevant in the classes. i'd like to just mark the whole class as relevant until i get a chance to drill down into that class.
*** Bug 166662 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I am running in similar problems. When adding a functionality to a web application, I know I will need to modify(add methods - they don't exist yet) to XyzHibernateDAO, XyzLogic, and XyzDRWProxy I wish to see these 3 files in the package explorer(with Mylyn filter on).
Porhaps add as landmark would be a bit to harsh, but in any case I would like to be able to augment Mylyn Usage Graph. Porhaps instead of Add as Landmark, there would be Increase importance - that tells Mylyn it should sky rocket the rating of the selected stuff in usage graph.
I find it self evident that using add as landmark should work "recursively" and on methods, classes, files and packages: that is if you select a java file it should add all the elements contained in it, and if you add a package it should add all the files contained in it and subsequenly all the elements contained in the each file. At least this is how I would imagine it to work.
Hope to see an improvement of this in the future releases of Mylyn.

Thanks for the feedback Alen. What is your favored interaction for getting to these three files in order to indicate that they are implicitly interesting? A few options are: 1) Use the Package Explorer and right-click 2) Use Open Resources (Ctrl+Shift+R) 3) Something else?
Let me know, and I'll propose a way that we can support this. Note that while "Remove from Context" works recursively, I don't htink that it would be a good idea for landmarking to work recursively because it could make a very large number of elements that may not be the target of interaction too interesting.

Thanks for showing intrest in my opinion Mik.
Ok, having implicit landmarking not working recursively is fine by me.
Yes, I use 1) and 2), but since one would normally select the important landmarks just once, if it is supported in just one place that I think would be sufficient.
One alternative way: I noticed that there are 2 tabs in the task editor: Planning and Context. Maybe when you are crating a new task, let say 'Task xyz' when done you could switch to context tab and somewhere specify to Mylyn - for this task there are some important things I wish to have around at all times and then specify a few key things.
I would like to have this feature too. I work primarily from the Navigator. I would like to be able to select one or more files there and mark the class(es).

New infrastructure was put in place for Mylyn 2.1 that can support this kind of functionality additional, although the inability to mark containers (e.g. Java files and packages) landmarks is still considered to be a feature not a bug (if not for this you would constantly see a bold compilation unit and bold class under it, which is visually redundant). We can investigate this policy further in the 2.2 timeframe. Also note that for 2.1 the popup menu actions won't misleadingly show up where they cannot operate (e.g. Mark as Landmark on a package node).
*** Bug 200443 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Fyi, more background on landmarking files is on bug 111165.

(In reply to comment #7) > landmarks is still considered to be a feature not a bug (if > not for this you would constantly see a bold compilation unit and bold class > under it, which is visually redundant).
This assumption is wrong when "Java Declaration Filter" is used in the Package Explorer. I think user should be able to freely mark any files as landmarks. Perhaps in that case class node won't need to be implicitly landmarked.

I'm probably not the most sophisticated eclipse user out there, and I'm more or less a brand-new mylyn user, but here are some notes on my use case:
1) I operate with the "Java Declaration Filter" on in package explorer. 2) When designing, prototyping, I often have many java files, most of which contain 'emtpy' classes.
These classes remain empty for a while until I'm ready to flesh out the concepts/pieces they represent, but It's important that I see them all at a glance because they are essentially 'notes' that I need to create funtionality later, and because looking at all of them at a glance gives me a quick overview of what my emerging design looks like. So, it gets annoying when I create a class/interface and then a few minutes later it "goes away". So, naturally, I think to add it manually to my context, but this is difficult because there is nothing that I can select in package explorer which is 'landmarkable', due to the 'Java Declaration Filter' being on.
So, why do I operate with that filter on? For me, seeing a zillion 'X.java' entries in package explorer, each with it's own 'X class' subentry, just ends up looking to cluttered. This gets especially cluttery when you add mylyn's bolding functionality.
I think I understand the thoughts about excessive bolding being something to avoid. But I wonder if there is room for a separate concept here - not quite a 'landmark', but something more than 'hidden from view'. Maybe the thing I'm looking for is not so much of a 'add to task focus' functionality for java files, packages, etc. but an 'add to task periphery' sort of concept. Or, to put it another way, sometimes I don't necessarily want to have a file be a 'landmark', but rather just 'on the map'. In the latter case, I wouldn't want it bolded anyway.

Stuart: thanks, that's a very useful summary. I'm currently of two minds on this:
1) We should discourage people from using the Java Declaration Filter, because with Mylyn the Package Explorer just ends up showing the exact same contents as the Ctrl+E list, which is almost as accessible and has the additional benefit that you can type at it.
2) We should accept that many people don't use the Ctrl+E list, and make a first-class model for the Package Explorer that causes declarations to be filtered and files to be landmarkable and show up in bold. All modes of this sort are confusing and add UI complexity, because when engaged the elements behave one way, and when not engaged another.
So I wonder if you could say more about why you use the Java Declaration Filter? I have heard many users give the very valid reason of the fact that their screen is too small and they see a scrollbar. I'm wondering whether getting rid of the scrollbar entirely (bug 178891) would address some of the need to hide declarations. I realize that there is some duplication when a lot of files with one class show. But what we work on when we code is types and members, not files, so if there is enough space I believe that it is desirable to encourage showing members in the Package Explorer, since they are very representive of the task context.

(In reply to comment #12) > So I wonder if you could say more about why you use the Java Declaration > Filter? I have heard many users give the very valid reason of the fact that > their screen is too small and they see a scrollbar. I'm wondering whether > getting rid of the scrollbar entirely (bug 178891) would address some of the > need to hide declarations.
My screen is fairly large (1920x1200) so I personally don't often run into any (justifiable) out-of-screen-space issues :)
> I realize that there is some duplication when a lot > of files with one class show. But what we work on when we code is types and > members, not files, so if there is enough space I believe that it is desirable > to encourage showing members in the Package Explorer, since they are very > representive of the task context.
My thinking behind using the Java Declarations Filter is something like this: When I think of a given project as a whole, I think in terms of packages & types/classes. Given Java's 'one class per file' bent, this more often than not boils down to a list of .java files. Of course the only time this breaks down is in the case of inner classes, but those are usually tied closely to the inner workings of their parent type. So, for the purposes of getting that high-level view, inner classes are not important to me to see. So, again, it's both the association between one .java file and one class, and the fact that any more info than 'there is a class named XYZ in package ABC' seems too fine grained for my tastes in a view of this sort (for anything that 'low', I use the 'Outline' view).
Maybe the simplest way to say all that is that I use the filter because:
1) I'd rather not see anything lower than '.java' (given that classes==.java files more or less one-to-one) in the package explorer view. 2) I already have that level of info in the 'Outline' view for the file I'm working on. 3) Because seeing that level of info in the package explorer view ruins my ability to use that view to quickly survey the landscape of my code.
As to ctl-E, I'd never used it before :) So I'm one of those users (at least I have been till now - nice trick! - I told you I wasn't the most sophisticated eclipse user in the world :) ).

(In reply to comment #12) > 1) We should discourage people from using the Java Declaration Filter, because > with Mylyn the Package Explorer just ends up showing the exact same contents as > the Ctrl+E list, which is almost as accessible and has the additional benefit > that you can type at it.
-1 for not using Java Declaration Filter too. The big difference with Ctrl-E is that ti is hierarchical and you have list before your eyes and with class elements it simply doesn't fit into the screen and there are too much details about class internals that are really belong to the Outline view. I often have 20+ files shown in the package explorer and there is simply no space on screen to show their details. Unfortunately currently both Package Explorer and Outline view have severe issues with filtering and they better be fixed before users stop using mylyn.
By the way, there is one of most ancient bugs related to this issue. See bug 143626

Fyi, I updated the corresponding FAQ entry some: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylyn_FAQ#How_do_I_stop_declarations_from_showing_in_the_Package_Explorer.3F
Stuart: thanks for your detailed answer. Some of the reasons you state are why we plan on continuing to support this feature, however, I believe that fixing bug 178891 will remove some of the use cases.
In terms of this bug, we have two options now: 1) Make Mark as Landmark be smart and work on Java File nodes by landmarking the first type in the file. 2) Allow Java file nodes to appear as bold, which could be useful when using the Filter Java Declarations mode.
I still hope to do (1) for 2.2.
Note that (2) would be very involved because it would require having custom decorations for Java file nodes that only work when Filter Java Declarations is enabled. If anyone wants this please file a new bug with the proposed UI, noting the discussion in bug 111165.

bug.short_desc: Support for custom EMF data types

long_desc.thetext:
We would like to be able to support properties (both singleton and collection) of EDataTypes that we define. An EMF custom data type is used to provide the clients of an EMF model with a Java class restricting the format of an underlying String that is persisted.
A straightforward custom data type is VersionNumber used to model the version of an Eclipse plugin. The Java class accepts integer major, minor, patch versions along with a qualifier String. It prevents clients of the EMF model to try to persist a character in the major, minor and patch segments of the version number. In XMI it is serialized as a String of the form major.minor.patch.qualifier. In the database, it is persisted the same way in a VARCHAR column.
Note that EMF custom data types could be modeled just like any other object. However, serialization would be to a different table with its own columns related by foreign key to the "owning" object. This does not perform as well as simply serializing the custom data type into the VARCHAR column of the "owning" object.
For more info about custom EMF data types see the "Data types" section of http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/iadthelp/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.emf.doc/references/overview/EMF.html
If you are interested in having Teneo support this functionality out-of-the-box then I can file a bugzilla and provide a patch that works with Hibernate using typedefs.The patch would also work for the cases below (given that they implement createFromString and convertToString as described in the link above):
Hans Mueller-Dieckert hmd@arcsolutions.de - Teneo: Hibernate and Arrays as EDataType
Chris Hines ChrisHines@msn.com - Teneo: storing custom EDataType attributes (i.e. java.io.File)
Thanks, -mike

Hi Mike, I understood that you have a patch for this functionality. Can you attach it to this bugzilla?
gr. Martin

Created an attachment (id=52736) an update to an existing Hibernate class (from latest in CVS revision 1.2).
A new method has been added to add typedefs for all the custom EDataTypes in the model. All new code is wrapped with Begin_CustomDataType and End_CustomDataType comments.

Created an attachment (id=52737) CustomDataTypeUserType.java - a new class for the Teneo distribution. It is a Hibernate UserType implementation to de/serialize the custom data type to/from the VARCHAR column.

Created an attachment (id=52738) Zipped up Eclipse plugin. Provides a test suite that serializes a Person object with some PhoneNumbers and ensures that it can be read back in from the store. You will need to update the dependencies
You will need to update the dependencies for Hibernate to work I did not provide that. Note that the test suite assumes HSQLDB.

Created an attachment (id=52739) Zipped up Eclipse plugin. A model plugin used by the test plugin attached before this file.
The test model plugin we will provide to Teneo has an example custom type that serializes USA phone numbers (see com.tibco.neo.orm.teneo.model.types.UsaPhoneNumber.java ) in the format: (xxx) xxx-xxxx
The test model plugin also defines an EDataType with name PhoneNumber that refers to the custom data type implementation. The Person object in this model has three properties: * name - a String holding the person's name * emergencyContact - a PhoneNumber to call if something happens to the person. * phoneNumbers - a list of PhoneNumbers to contact the person at.

TIBCO Software Inc. is contributing the attached files with the Eclipse Public License to the Teneo project to provide the enhancement:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=162339
How can Hibernate be configured to persist custom data types?
Hibernate does not know about EMF custom data types. It has a mechanism for defining new types - it is called a [http://www.hibernate.org/hib_docs/v3/reference/en/html_single/#mapping-types-custom UserType]. TIBCO is providing the CustomDataTypeUserType implementation to persist EMF custom data types to a VARCHAR column. This UserType implementation requires calling the EMF model package implementation to transform values from Strings to the custom data type and vice-versa. Therefore, this UserType implementation must be configured with the following two properties:
* packageImplementationClassName - the full class name of the EMF model package implemenation.
* attributeName - the name of the attribute in the package that holds the EMF EDataType configuration.
Now Hibernate has to be configured to use this UserType. Hibernate supports the notion of a typedef
http://www.hibernate.org/hib_docs/v3/reference/en/html_single/#mapping-types-custom
defined at the top of the Hibernate mapping. The importance of configuring this UserType as a typedef means that both properties and collections will resolve the mapping correctly. The type cannot be associated directly with the properties of the classes because Hibernate collection properties don't support the parameterized type configuration.
Here is a sample configuration of the typedef in the Hibernate mapping for the test suite included in this message: <hibernate-mapping> <typedef name="test.com.tibco.teneo.model.types.UsaPhoneNumber" class="org.eclipse.emf.teneo.hibernate.types.VarcharToEmfCustomDataTypeUserType"> <param name="packageImplementationClassName">test.com.tibco.teneo.model.testteneomodel.impl.TestteneomodelPackageImpl</param> <param name="attributeName">PhoneNumber</param> <class .../> </hibernate-mapping>
Note that the typedef name is the EMF custom data type class name. Properties/collections in the classes of the Hibernate mapping simply define this class as the type for the property/collection. The actual class instantiated when the POJO is loaded is the UserType implementation specified. It is configured with the package implementation and attribute name - enough information to call the conversion methods to convert a String from to the UsaPhoneNumber Java object and back again.
How can Teneo be modified to configure Hibernate?
Now the question is how to modify Elver to insert the typedef(s) at the top of the Hibernate mapping it generates.
First, when using Teneo to access the Hibernate {{{SessionFactory}}}, a {{{HbDataStore}}} instance must be instantiated. TIBCO has extended the Teneo HibernateMappingGenerator implementation with new methods to insert the typedefs into the Hibernate mapping xml. The extension of HibernateMappingGenerator walks over all the EClassifiers in all the EPackages that the HbDataStore was given. If the EClassifier represents a custom data type that has not already been seen and is not handled by Hibernate natively, then a typedef is added at the top the Hibernate mapping generated by Teneo. Teneo then proceeds as normal. That is it.
As for your question on supporting annotations, the EDataType elements can support the Type annotation but that is pretty useless since the EDataType is configured with the exact same information that the Type annotation would provide (an implementation class name of the custom data type). I view the EDataType configuration itself as being almost equivalent to an annotation.
Please let me know if you have any questions regarding this submission. Thanks, Michael Kanaley Principal Architect TIBCO Software Inc.

Thanks for your contribution Mike,
I will look at this next week.
I agree with your remark that an edatatype corresponds to a typedef annotation.
gr. Martin

Hi Mike, A few questions (after a glance at your proposal). Afaics your proposal assumes that all custom types should be stored in a (one) varchar column. Is this correct?
Why have you used the name 'attributeName' and not 'edatatype' to denote the name of the edatatype (in the parameter)? I am asking because naming sometimes reflects a deeper idea about a certain approach (so I am curious if there is a certain approach reflected in this name).
Your solution assumes that there is an actual implementation class for the EPackage (so won't work for dynamic emf). I would think that passing the nsuri as a parameter would also work. What do you think?
gr. Martin

> Hi Mike, > A few questions (after a glance at your proposal). > Afaics your proposal assumes that all custom types should be stored in a > (one) > varchar column. Is this correct? Yes. The idea is that if it was more than one column, the EDataType would be modeled as an EClass instead. Also, according to EMF's documentation, the EDataType must be serializable to/from a String - which points at using a VARCHAR column. The column length annotation can be applied to properties if the default VARCHAR column length (255?) is not big enough.
Note that this patch should not create typedefs for java.sql.Blob/Clob EDataType implementations since they are handled by Hibernate natively.
> Why have you used the name 'attributeName' and not 'edatatype' to denote > the > name of the edatatype (in the parameter)? I am asking because naming > sometimes > reflects a deeper idea about a certain approach (so I am curious if there > is a > certain approach reflected in this name). No deep meaning here. Actually, edatatype name would be more appropriate.
> Your solution assumes that there is an actual implementation class for the > EPackage (so won't work for dynamic emf). I would think that passing the > nsuri > as a parameter would also work. What do you think? That sounds like the right way to do it. I see now how to instantiate the EPackage from the nsuri using the global registry. There certainly are alot of ways to skin the EMF cat. Thanks for the useful comments and considering this enhancement. -mike
> > gr. Martin

Hi Mike, I understand your point of serialization to string of an edatatype. However this is also because of xml/xmi serialization support (I think).
I agree that multiple column types can be modeled using a class (embedded in the table of the parent for example). However, I do not think that this applies to all cases (why would hibernate otherwise support CompositeUserType). There can also be single column non-string cases.
So I would like a more generic approach in which a user can specify his/her own hibernate UserType. This can be supported by adding typedef annotation support on edatatypes. This would also support parametering of the usertype through annotations.
Currently Teneo uses a DefaultAnnotator which tries to make sensible choices regarding annotations for different model elements. So what I want to do is adapt (Hibernate)DefaultAnnotator to add a default typedef annotation to an edatatype which does not have a manual typedef annotation. The default will be single column varchar approach as you contributed here.
The hibernate mapping logic will then use the typedef annotations to generate the typedef mappings in the top of the mapping xml.
So this is a variation of your approach which offers some more flexibility to the developer.
What do you think of this approach?
gr. Martin
Your approach that supports a CompositeUserType sounds great to me. Thanks, -mike

Support for this has been added in cvs. The system now supports the type annotation on an eattribute and typedef on edatatype. If an edatatype does not have a typedef and its instanceclass can not be handled by hibernate then automatically a typedef annotation is created which maps the edatatype to a single varchar column (as proposed below).
If you are on cvs, there is a new project/plugin which also needs to be checked out: org.eclipse.emf.teneo.hibernate.mapper.
gr. Martin

bug.short_desc: Wrong selection in package explorer when try to open via double-click on focused view

long_desc.thetext: When I try to open a item (from package explorer) via double-click the selected item changed between first click and second one. It seemed that between first and second left click TreeViewer-ul made a refresh and changed the item under cursor.
This happens due to the lazy refresh of the view not getting rid of decayed elements until you click. It assume that it is rare, but it is definitely a bit annoying when it happens.
Note to self: we may be able to fix this by changing or removing the use of FocusedViewerManager.VIEWR_PART_TRACKER.

Removed viewer part tracker. The side effect is that in some cases the viewer will not refresh until a selection is made, but it prevents refresh on activation.
Antonel: if you still see any problematic behavior like this with the Mylar 2.0M2 please reopen.

bug.short_desc: Add change notification to DebugOptions service

long_desc.thetext:
Please add methods for (de)registering change listeners with the DebugOptions. Polling calls to getOptions() are comparingly expensive and calls to setOption() should be be seldom enough to justify the runtime overhead.
This seems especially important/interesting in server-side environments, where tracing should be modifiable without a server restart.

This seems like a fine requirement. However I don't think we need to roll out an event mechanism, and should use the service events (registered, unregistered, modified) instead. To me the biggest challenge is not in making this service dynamic, but rather in making all the users of this service react accordingly to the changes.
So, would you would you be able to contribute some code? Thx.

I'm willing to spend some time to make this happen but I'm not sure how service events can be used for notifying about debug option changes. If you explain that to me I could be able to provide an initial patch.
I find it interesting that everybody starts to worry about how to make users react on changes now ;-) As I said in the newsgroup, change was always possible and it was silently accepted that clients don't react to it, possibly due to the lack of efficient API to do so (pollong was the only means). With my proposal efficient reaction becomes feasible, it should be even easier to convince users to react on changes. On the other hand I believe that not all users of the DebugOptions service really need to react on changes.

the correct link is: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/enter_bug.cgi?classification=STP Fixed

bug.short_desc: Implementing a preference page incomplete.

long_desc.thetext:
The 3.2 Platform Plugin Developer Guide has a page called "Implementing a preference page". It makes sense up to "Retrieving and saving preferences". This section describes manual save and restore logic. That section seems to contradict the next page, "Field editors". It appears that Field Editors do the save and restore. Or not, I cannot tell. Suggestion add sentence:
Once you've associated your plug-in's preference store with your preference page, you can implement the logic for retrieving and saving the preferences. Or use the FieldEditors described on the next page.
On Field Editors page, change:
Since the preference page is associated with a preference store (specified in the doGetPreferenceStore method), the code for storing the current values, for initializing the control values from the preference store, and for restoring the controls to their default values **are** all be implemented in the FieldEditorPreferencePage. The functions initializeValue(), storeValues() and initializeDefaults() from Implementing a preference page are not needed.
Equally perplexing is to understand how preferences get there initial values. So in "Retrieving and saving preferences" we see initializeValues() setting controls with values form the store. Great...how did those values get into the store in the first place? Above we read about initializeDefaultPreferences(store):
These values are used the first time the preference page is shown or when the user presses the Defaults button in the preferences page.
but what about the store ** before ** the page is shown the first time?
I don't have a suggestion since I don't understand it.
This confusion is compounded by so many ways the documentation and platform uses the word "preferences". Runtime-, project scoped-, plugin-, services- preferences: do they have anything to do with the IPreferenceStore from AbstractUIPlugin? Rather than a link to "Runtime preferences" on the main "Preference pages", a better solution would be a description of how a Perference Page relates to the stuff on that page. Otherwise they don't seem to have any connection other than the link.

The 3.2 doc page
Implementing a preference page
starts with
The JFace plug-in provides a framework for implementing wizards, preference pages, and dialogs. The implementation for these dialogs follows a common pattern.
But no where in the article is the JFace plugin named and in particular which class I should use for preferences pages. The entire common pattern thing isn't very important to users: we want to implement a preference page as the title offers.
A better start might be
A prefence page must implement the IWorkbenchPreferencePage interface. You can start with a FieldEditorPreferencePage (link page) or create your own as we outline here. The contents of a page or dialog is defined by implementing a createContents method that ...
Then after the code,
This kind of code is common in eclipse applications based on JFace. The JFace plug-in provides a framework for implementing wizards, preference pages, and dialogs. The implementation for these dialogs follows a common pattern

bug.short_desc: [DataBinding] Integrating XSWT, Data Binding, and databases

long_desc.thetext:
I've summerized some of my thoughts in a document (just started more to come in next days).
I have already a (SQL-Database)-SWT-Databinding-Framework written (which used internally in about 10 applications) and it would be great if we could take the best of all the projects and code around and create a new and really cool Eclipse-Addon which provides developers an easy but powerfully and extensible framework for data-centric applications.
In the answer to Sebastien you write that there are already databinding capabilities built into XSWT I think we should fall back to the old style mixing presentation and model (this time in XML) which in my idea is not a good thing because this would force implementors to built their applications upon XSWT which they maybe don't want ;-) . Say people because of what ever reason want to use AUIML, ... to define the GUI (maybe a format their GUI emits :-) .
Having said all this here are some links to:
- Experiments how things could work: ------------------------------------ Source http://publicsvn.bestsolution.at/repos/java/at.bestsolution.dataforms/trunk/
Spec Document http://publicsvn.bestsolution.at/repos/java/at.bestsolution.dataforms/trunk/design/EclipseDataAppliance.pdf
- Current Databinding used internally: -------------------------------------- Source http://publicsvn.bestsolution.at/repos/java/products/at.bestsolution.cashaccounting/trunk/
Bin-Release to tryout: http://publicsvn.bestsolution.at/repos/java/products/at.bestsolution.cashaccounting/bin-releases/0.0.1/

Tom

Now that we have a stabile API >> >> for Databinding soon: I'd like to think about a Framework above >> >> Databinding. >> >> >> >> There are somethings coming to my mind: >> >> --------------------------------------- >> >> - Abstract XML Definition of a DataForm in XML and connect it to various >> >> datasources (SQL-Database, LDAP, ... ) => XSWT + XDL (eXtensible >> >> Dataform Language :-) >> >> - Exensibility something like: >> >> MainForm contributed by plugin A >> >> - SubForm1 contributed by plugin A >> >> - SubForm2 contributed by plugin B >> >> - Userrights management, ... >> >> - provide API for Scripting Engines something like the Browsers DOM >> >> called FOM (Form Object Model)? >> >> >> >> Any one interested? >> >> >> >> Tom >> >> >> >> Sbastien Letli schrieb: >>> >>> Hi Boris, Hi Dave, >>> >>> >>> >>> I finalize my RCP application which uses XSWT/JFace Data >>> >>> Binding/Hibernate/BIRT. bug.short_desc: Code merge functionalities in Service Creation

long_desc.thetext:
In code generation, there alway be a code-merge problem. for example, when the user change some thing in the source file and the build re-generate the code, which will conflict with the previously-generated one.
Simply overwriting the old ones is not a better option. A merge scheme should be designed for this.
*** Bug 165739 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
added code merge support as following: the new code will be generated in src/gen_temp dir. then we merge the new code with existing code.

bug.short_desc: refactor the code-gen page to be more generic

long_desc.thetext: Code-gen needs to be generic to any code-gen tools, not only cxf tool. probably a new extension point should be defined to enable a tool to be plugged in.

i had some thought about that a while ago and at the time i had a couple of sketch of ideas, both of them involving extending the extension point:
#1 the existing interface used by the current gen extension point could be extended to have new methods like: - Map<String, Class> getParamList() with the class defining the type of the param (e.g String.class, boolean.class, some enum class) ... in order to simplify wizard generation, we might have to restrict the possible types (e.g. no list or complex types) - run(Map<String, Object>) with the OBject being the actual value of te param - setParam(String name, Object value) - Map<String, Object> getParamDefaults()
#2 extend the schema of the extension point to allow the registration of param slots with attributes like : name, type class (limited to simple types and enums), literal default and/or initializer class, free text description,
in both cases a basic wizard content could be generated dynamically based on that info but if the user want to write it down we might have to leave an option for the users to register a specific wizard impl (via an interface we would control)

The eclipse preference page extension point design can be borrowed to solve this issue. That is we define a new interface which has the following methods:
createContents() allow it to create its own GUI to specify parameters. performOK() to notify it to store the paramter values Map getParameters() to collect the paramters and pass it to the Generator's run() method.
the runtimeProvider extension point has been enhanced to allow cxf tooling to provide tool-specific paramters for the code-gen.

The annotation validator should validate the syntax of standard jax-ws and jaxb out of box. And user can customize it to fit the requirement of their tool, such as particular requirements for celtixfire

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.testSimpleStepFilter/testInactiveStepFilter depend on VM behavior

long_desc.thetext:
These two tests fail on the JRockit JVM.
When the tests step into a method that is executed for the first time and depends has calls to classes that are not yet loaded, JVM behavior differs. This happens with the step from StepFilterOne.go() into StepFilterTwo.test() (which calls System.out.println()).
In a JVM with an interpreter the JVM can step to the first instructions in StepFilterTwo.test() without loading any classes. The class loading can happen when the call is made. In a JVM that JIT-compiles all methods (read JRockit), the class loading needs to happen before the method can be compiled, "during" the step operation. Class loading involves running Java code. This means that the next step point will be inside the class loading code and not (as the test expects) inside StepFilterTwo.test().
[Let me know if the explanation above is unclear and I'll try to clarify.]

I've modified the test case to avoid calling System.out.println(...). This should avoid loading the system classes. As well, the test case is modified to load all the test classes before performing the stepping. I think this should fix the problem.
Released to HEAD.
Staffan, can you verify this resolves the test failure on JRockit? Thanks.
Yes, it does resolve the issue. Many thanks!
Back ported the test to the 3.2 maintenance branch.
Marking as 3.2.2 since it was fixed there as well.

bug.short_desc: Keyword substitution changes are not seen by other clients

long_desc.thetext:
We have a fair number of files that were accidentally created and checked into CVS using binary mode. I find that I have to change the keyword substitution mode on every client.
That is, if I have a file myfile.xml that shows up as binary, then I change the ascii/binary property, which does a commit to CVS, that client then shows the file correctly in the package explorer as binary.
If I then do a synchronize on another client, I see the change in CVS, and I update the client. However, the file still shows as binary in the package explorer.
Having the binary/ascii property wrong on a client can cause problems in a multi-platform team - we have some using Windows, some Linux. When there is a discrepancy like this, it sometimes happens that if a patch is created, even though only a single line has changed, the patch shows everything deleted and then everything added. This is probably the expected behavior when a file is binary, but I point it out simply to explain tha having the keyword substitution not propagate causes ongoing problems.
I do not know enough about how keyword substitution works in CVS to know if this could be a CVS issue and not an eclipse issue.
This is a server issue. If you change files from binary to text, you need to instruct all developers to re-checkout the project.

bug.short_desc: MethodVerifier#areReturnTypesEqual is a misnomer

long_desc.thetext: The method implementation is not symetrical. What it does is to check whether its parameters have equal return types, or else if the first one has a return type compatible with the one of the second one, under specific conditions (one of these conditions being that the caller be an instance of MethodVerifier15). Unfortunately, areReturnTypesCompatible already exists... Hence clarification of the topic is needed before any action is taken.

A couple of remarks: - the only uses (in JDT Core - but method verifiers are non-API classes) of the existing areReturnTypesCompatible are in implementations of areReturnTypesEqual; - areReturnTypesEqual is called from inheritance verification code and from areMethodsEqual, which is a misnomer of its own (since it checks whether one method overrides the other and has a compatible return type, which is probably not what 'Equal' suggests).
I would then propose to: - rename areMethodsEqual to areMethodsCompatible; - keep the existing areReturnTypesCompatible, - but implement a new method called bypassFurtherCompatibilityChecks that would introduce the nuance between method verifiers.
Will post a patch along those lines.

Created an attachment (id=62357) Suggested fix
After playing a bit with the code, I preferred to delegate part of the check to a worker method (suffixed by 0) when needed only. With this patch, areReturnTypesCompatible always returns immediately if types are identical, or else selectively (depending on compatibility levels) proceed with further checks.
Kent, please let me know what you think.
Released for 3.3 M7.
Verified for 3.3M7 using I20070427-0010

bug.short_desc: When adding a new extension, add children automatically

long_desc.thetext:
When I add in a new extension point via PDE, I pick one from the menu (e.g. org.eclipse.debug.ui.launchShortcuts). This DTD looks like:
<!ELEMENT extension (shortcut*)> <!ELEMENT shortcut (perspective* , contextualLaunch? , enablement?)> ...
http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/extension-points/org_eclipse_debug_ui_launchShortcuts.html
When I create a new extension point, it's a given I want to create at least one shortcut (otherwise I wouldn't be doing it). Can't we determine, from the DTD, what the required element is, and in the case of a single one such as (shortcut*), instantiate an empty shortcut that I can populate?
The fact that you have to right click an extension point and do 'add' a second time (to add an XML child to it) is non-intuitive for a beginners point of view.
More generally, it might be worth populating the extension point with an empty document that exercises all (non-deprecated) elements. However, this probably wouldn't be useful for elements such as 'enablement' in the DTD; more generally, anything like ELEMENT x (a,b,c,d,e)* is probably going to be a node that you wouldn't want to recurse further in generation of a template XML document.
This would be especially useful for XML documents that are defined as ELEMENT x (a+), since you must have at least one 'a' for the document to be valid.
Even if you can't generalise this to support arbitrary DTDs and arbitrary nesting, it would make sense for the first level of pluing (in this case, shortcut) to be instantiated; because adding an extension point and leaving it empty is an incredibly uncommon use-case. In any case, if it wasn't what the user wanted they can always delete it afterwards.

Good suggestion. I actually was planning on implementing this within the 3.3. M3-M4 time period. This functionality already exists in PDE on the plug-in manifest XML source page via XML content assist. All that is required is to migrate this mechanism into Extensions form page.
The mechanism automatically and recursively generates all required elements and attributes using information from the corresponding extension point schema (respecting minimum multiplicity constraints and drilling down as many levels as necessary).
It is important to note that the mechanism will only generate all unambigous and non-optional elements and attributes. For instance, when a choice is encountered, the algorithm will not be presumptuous and choose for the user - opting instead to leave that branch empty. Similarly, in your shortcut example, nothing will be generated because according to the extension point schema (perhaps a bug in the schema), shortcut elements are not mandatory.
To get an idea of what the behaviour will look like, try using XML content assist on a few extensions and child elements of those extensions.
In the Extensions form page, the plan is to invoke the mechanism as described when and extension is first selected and when subsequent elements are selected via the right context menu. The goal is to minimize the amount of right-clicking required by the user.

I still think that at the top level, if an element is of the form (thing)*, then there's no reason not to generate one child. Quite a lot of the DTDs that have this form, and without generating at least one child (i.e. just having <extension/>) is a bit pointless.
Good points re: choices etc. though. And the goal of creating less stuff is certainly useful
PS Might be worth looking through all extension points to find out if the root element is always of the form (thing)*. My guess is that most, if not all, of them well be like this form; which means not instantiating one element will result in little effect.

re comment 2:
I'd rather see the extension point schemas getting fixed up by their owners, rather than have PDE do special cases with regards to *.

To a certain extent, I'd agree with you -- but there's always the backward compatibility angle to consider that may make such things impractical or impossible.
Turning it around, if the root element is (thing)*, what's the problem with generating one? It's not like any of the extension points at present could exist without any form of children, is it? Given that the extension point is defined as:
<!ELEMENT extension ANY> <!ATTLIST extension point CDATA #REQUIRED id CDATA #IMPLIED name CDATA #IMPLIED >
I don't see a situation in which <extension point="point" id="id" name="name"/> would ever be useful. And even if there are cases where it *is* useful, it's still not going to be the default in well over 99% of cases. So, what's the problem with optimising for the common 99% of cases and allow the user to delete the singleton child if they don't want it? Like you said, it's about trying to reduce the work that the users have to do.

There is nothing wrong with generating one.
It is just that part of me thinks that enough is enough, and things have to be corrected at the right level, instead of continuing to mask problems.

I know what you mean :-)
The problem (as always) is it's likely to come down to backward compatibility. If there's a plugin out there that accidentally has an empty <extension/> element, and it validates by today's DTD, then it's difficult to argue for changing it so that it becomes invalid.
Of course, I don't think anyone uses the DTD to validate (but I could be wrong?) but if you can convince everyone to change the DTDs from (thing)* to (thing)+, great :-)
If not, I think it would be useful to have this as a feature when generating new extension points. Heck, even if we can convince the DTDs to change, it still might be useful generating a singleton against a top-level (thing)* -- just make it an optional checkbox or something in the new extension point wizard.

You bring up a sore point with me when you talk about backward compatibility.
Unfortunately, mistakes in extension point schema specifications, such as element multiplicity or attribute type, have, up until now, been "effectively" regarded as documentation changes. Extension point owners should be more careful when specifying schemas and treat them with the same respect as they do with their Java API
PDE is currently cracking down on these cases with extra validation on plugin.xml files: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg07605.html
As for the + vs * issue at hand, it would best if the teams fixed them up regardless. At the same time, since PDE is in the business of making developers' lives easier anyway, it would certainly be helpful to automatically add a child to an extension even if there is a *, as long as there is no ambiguity (ie. a choice)
So I leave it to Mike to assess the situation and decide what's best. By definition, PDE should be helpful, but we should not be investing in hacks that could be avoided if the schemas were properly spec'ed out in the first place.

Didn't mean to bring up a sore point ...
I was specifically thinking of elements of the form (thing)*, rather than (thing,otherthing)* when I suggested it, so your example of choice is something that I agree wouldn't make sense to do automatically.
Also, I think it would make sense to raise individual bugs for updating the extension point schemas. Perhaps the PDE could validate when you have an extension point of (stuff,otherstuff)* and prompt to change to + instead, when it's a root element.

Fixed.
Target: 3.3 M4 Patch: patch_162379_2006-11-10_16-34 Patch released to HEAD
Overview:
I agree with Wassim with respect to the top level element of form (thing)* issue on technical and philosophical grounds. However, Alex's prediction in Comment # 2 turned out to be correct. Pretty much 99% of all extension point schemas containing one root element use '*' rather than '+'. Actually, embarrassingly enough PDE's own extension point schemas do too ! So on practical grounds I implemented the feature.
Work Done:
* Hooked in XML content assist recursive element / attribute generation mechanism in the following parts -> New extension wizard - Invoked via 'Add' button and 'New->Extension' right context menu in Extensions page -> New element action - Invoked via 'New->{element-name}' right context menu in Extensions page -> i.e. Requirements listed in Comment # 1
* Detect and handle the following edge case: Extension element has a non-null sequence compositor that has a min occurs of one and contains one child element whose min occurs is zero -> i.e. Requirements listed in Comment # 2 -> Essentially, the child element is interpreted as having a min occurs of one and is auto-generated accordingly

>Actually, embarrassingly enough PDE's own extension point schemas do too !
It may be more embarrassing than you think.
Up until and including Eclipse 2.0, PDE owned and maintained all extension point schemas. It was hell, but I digress. In 2.1, we donated them to their respective teams who have since took over the task.
So it is very possible that we are not only guilty of using *, we may have started the trend in the first place ;)
Cool :-) I look forward to testing it out soon ...
