bug.short_desc: [Indexer][Scanner] Strange null characters during C source parsing

long_desc.thetext:
I'm developing NS chart generator for C source code based on Eclipse CDT. During development, I experienced bad performance & OutOfMemory Error caused by CDT indexer.
I tried identifying what was wrong at debug mode and found a strange thing.
During parsing C source, so many IASTProblem objects are generated in DOMScanner.handleProblem() and cause OutOfMemory Error. As I understand, These objects are generated to log SCANNER_BAD_CHARACTER problems. In detail, the problem is caused by null character( '\0' ) found in C source.
many null character => many IASTProblem objects => OutOfMemory Error.
In order to identify which source includes null character, I modify BaseScanner.fetchToken() as following,
BaseScanner.java line 2026 ============================================ // skip over anything we don't handle char [] x = new char [1]; x[0] = buffer[pos]; if( x[0] == '\0') { System.out.println("Suspicious String:"); int s = Math.max(0, pos-100); for( int i=s; i<pos; i++ ){ System.out.print( buffer[i]); } System.out.println(); }else { handleProblem( IASTProblem.SCANNER_BAD_CHARACTER, pos, x ); } ============================================
I tested it using Apache Httpd 2.2.3 source code and I got following log. This log was generated during parsing "mod_auth_basic.c" file and logged string was part of "ap_config.h". But, "ap_config.h" file did not include any null character.
============================================ Suspicious String: VERSION__ >= 199901L) #define AP_HAVE_DESIGNATED_INITIALIZER #endif
#endif /* AP_CONFIG_H */
Suspicious String: ERSION__ >= 199901L) #define AP_HAVE_DESIGNATED_INITIALIZER #endif
#endif /* AP_CONFIG_H */
Suspicious String: RSION__ >= 199901L) #define AP_HAVE_DESIGNATED_INITIALIZER #endif
#endif /* AP_CONFIG_H */ ============================================
I guess that unintentional null charaters are appended to buffer during macro extenstion of C source file and these cause waste of CPU and memory.
Because I don't understand CDT inside, My guess may be wrong or right.
Please check my guess, and I hope my observation would be helpful to improve CDT.
In addition, I found linear search logic for long array from several position of CDT source code. As we know, performance of linear search is O(n) or in proportion to data size. so I think we can consider changing it into other algorithm as binary search for handling heavy project. ( of course, only when the array is sorted )
examples of method using linear search for array. ============================ ArrayUtil.append() _CompositeContext.findContextContainingOffset() LocationMap.getLocation()

As summary, In my PC ( it is old and very slow :) ), I tested fast indexer using Apache Httpd 2.2.3 source project.
when using original CDT core, my eclipse crashed after about 4 minutes with OutOfMemory Error generating 300KB PDOM index.
when using CDT core modified by me, my eclipse completed index after about 4 minute generating 4MB PDOM index.
Following is my modification : 1. modify CodeReader.load() in order to avoid unintentional null character. 2. replace linear search algorithm with binary search algorithm in following mehtods, ArrayUtil.append() _CompositeContext.findContextContainingOffset() LocationMap.getLocation()
regards,

(In reply to comment #2) > Following is my modification : > 1. modify CodeReader.load() in order to avoid unintentional null character. > 2. replace linear search algorithm with binary search algorithm in following > mehtods, > ArrayUtil.append() > _CompositeContext.findContextContainingOffset() > LocationMap.getLocation() > regards, Can you help out by providing a patch?

(In reply to comment #3) > (In reply to comment #2) > Can you help out by providing a patch?
I think publishing new patch is beyond my authority and I already submit all information that I found for authorized developers of CDT.
Most of all, because I don't understand CDT inside well, I can not sure my modification has no side effect. we need careful check of experts before applying something.
regards,

> I think publishing new patch is beyond my authority > and I already submit all information that I found for authorized developers of > CDT. Everybody that has a bugzilla account can attach patches to bugs. See http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/CDT/contributing
> Most of all, because I don't understand CDT inside well, I can not sure my > modification has no side effect. we need careful check of experts before > applying something. A patch will be applied only after it has been looked at. You seem to have enough expertise to provide helpful input.

Created an attachment (id=52833) avoid unexpected null character problem
it slightly change way to get character array from C source file.

Created an attachment (id=52834) improve search of long array and avoid unexpected null character
in addition attachment #52833, it changes search logic of long array from linear search into binary search.
but I'm not sure my change is correct or not. please check.

Even though my suggested patches are based on source code in CVS( it may be 4.0.0 rc? ), My investigation covered CDT 3.1.1 not 4.0.
Actually, I have seen CDT 4.0 code first time only to make patch files, and I feel CDT 4.0 is somewhat different from 3.1.1 in many points of view. Maybe my patches can not apply to CDT 4.0, I think.
with CDT core 4.0.0(?), I tested fast index facility on Apache Httpd 2.2.3 project.
when my patches was not applied: About 4 minutes later since indexer started, eclipse crashed with OutOfMemory Error and 300KB index file.
after applying attachment #52833, About 20 minutes later since indexer started, Indexer was still working and generated 2MB index file. I stopped indexer by force.
after applying attachment #52834, About 20 minutes later since indexer started, Indexer was still working and generated 20MB index file. I stopped indexer by force.
Actually, I was surprised the result because I expected indexing would complete with 4MB index file in 4~5 minutes just like CDT 3.1.1 after applying attachment #52834.
regards,

Thanks Jeong-Sik! I have applied your first patch. There were bugs in the second one, I have made changes to the LocationMap along your ideas. I stayed away from changing ArrayUtil, see bug 162755.
Fixed in 4.0 > 20061030.

bug.short_desc: Java Web Start problem with bundle naming

long_desc.thetext:
Hi, I encoutered problem after upgrading from 3.2 to 3.2.1 in launching RCP product with JWS. I was getting sudden crash on the very startup with log message: java.lang.NullPointerException at java.util.Hashtable.put(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.WebStartMain.basicRun(WebStartMain.java:58) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:973) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.WebStartMain.main(WebStartMain.java:40) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.executeApplication(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.executeMainClass(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.continueLaunch(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.handleApplicationDesc(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.handleLaunchFile(Unknown Source) at com.sun.javaws.Launcher.run(Unknown Source) at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
I traced it down and solved. Problematic line is System.getProperties().put(PROP_FRAMEWORK, fwkURL);
which fails b/c fwkURL is null. It is null, because earlier org.eclipse.osgi wasn't resolved to proper URL in method mapURLsToBundleList. And it wasn't resolved b/c the key bundle org.eclipse.osgi has two '_' (underscore) signs in its name in 3.2.1. It is named org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.1.R32x_v20060919.jar and see the following snipped from mapURLsToBundleList
if (bundleURLs == null) { int versionIdPosition = bundleId.lastIndexOf('_'); if (versionIdPosition == -1) continue; bundleURLs = (ArrayList) bundleList.get(bundleId.substring(0, versionIdPosition)); if (bundleURLs == null) continue; }
I cured the problem erasing one underscore from org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.1.R32x_v20060919.jar to org.eclipse.osgi_3.2.1.R32xv20060919.jar and changing the rcp's JNLP file.
But in fact either the naming should change (like other bundles use - or dots instead of _) or the algorithm in WebStartMain
best regards, Michal Kostrzewa
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 162097 ***

bug.short_desc: annotation view fails to recognize annotation if they are spcified via their fully qualified name

bug.short_desc: annotation wizards: need to provide a page per annotation

agreed with johnson

bug.short_desc: annotation wizards: the ouput of the wizards should be customizable for specific runtime providers

long_desc.thetext:
package: org.eclipse.stp.sc.jaxws.packages
As it stands, the annotation wizards outputs not customizable.
however we cannot expect that the current output will be sufficient or adapted to every provider.
So we should add an optional element to the provider extension point in order to specified the required annotation to be produce by the wizards

Already made some preparative work to help on this: - streamlined the annotation attribute pages to only one reusable class - added an instance attribute "ANNOTATION_REQUIRED" to the CreateAnnotationWizard class as a starting point to a central mechanism to control the content of the wizards - generalized the access to the wizards data model via a few convenience methods in the CreateAnnotationWizard class
The next step looks like actually writing the necessary extension point cpts...
not applicable anymore
not applicable anymore

bug.short_desc: Calculation of target platform appears not to take versions into account

long_desc.thetext:
I've got a patched version of a core plugin (org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.2.1.v20060303-PATCHED) installed in my eclipse\plugins folder, along with the standard org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.2.1.v20060303. The name of the Jar matches the Bundle-Version in the Manifest.MF (well, the Bundle-Version is 3.2.0 in both places, but the suffix is the same).
When starting Eclipse, it picks the right version, and Help -> About -> plugin details indicates that the patched version is being used.
However, when running a runtime PDE app, the Help -> About -> plugin details shows that the unpatched version is being used.
Going to Window -> Preferences -> Plug-in Development -> Target Platform -> Reload didn't come up with the new version. It always resolved to the 3.2.1.v20060303 version.
In the end, the only way I could run with the right target version was to close eclipse, delete the unpatched version, re-start eclipse, and then go itno the target platform. It's now showing up as org.eclipse.equinox.common (3.2.0.v20060303-PATCHED), and when I run the target workspace, it comes up with the right version there too.
Does the 'reload' take into account the qualifier when doing the searching for plugins, or does it just hit the first one it finds?

>Going to Window -> Preferences -> Plug-in Development -> Target Platform -> >Reload didn't come up with the new version. It always resolved to the >3.2.1.v20060303 version.
is this step taking place in the host (first) instance of Eclipse or the runtime (second) instance?
is your target platform the same as the host platform?

1st Eclipse instance shows the -PATCHED bundle in use via Help->About->Plugins
2nd Eclipse instance (launched as a runtime Eclipse application from 1st instance) shows the non -PATCHED bundle in Help->About->Plugins, and shows sign of the bug that the patch was designed for :-)
There wasn't a specific target platform specified, so the 2nd instance is defaulting to the 1st instance's plugins (but using a different workspace, obviously). I.e. both 1st Eclipse and 2nd Eclipse were using c:\same\eclipse\plugins folder.

What build of 3.2.1 are you using?
I tried to reproduce this on the 9/21 build of 3.2.1 and was not successful. Just to make sure I am testing this correctly, here is what I did. I copied the org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.2.0.v20060603.jar. Extracted all the files, modified the Manifest to change the Bundle-Version to 3.2.0.v20060603-PATCHED. Then zipped up the files into a new jar named org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.2.0.v20060603-PATCHED.jar. I then included this jar in the plugins directory of my 3.2.1 installation (along with the original org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.2.0.v20060603.jar).
With this set up, Both the host (first version) and the runtime (second instance) both reflected the -PATCHED version in the Help > About > Plugins.

So far so good ... but what you need to do is to launch a new runtime PDE instance inside Eclipse. So, Eclipse A has both the .jar and -PATCHED.jar, whilst Eclipse B (launched from within Eclipse A) will only see the .jar.
Alex.

I believe I have this same problem in build i1129. My steps were:
- extract Eclipse - drop a second version of JUnit into the plug-ins directory (should be able to just copy v3.8.2 and change the version number) - start Eclipse
Note: only a single (latest) version appears on the Target Platform prefs page. Note: in the manifest editor when trying to add a bundle dependancy, only one version appears in the list.
Sorry, I should have also mentioned that I am running with the OSGi console and have confirmed that both versions are in the RESOLVED state.
I believe this is a dup of bug 44512?

bug.short_desc: Create a test around the strict mode

long_desc.thetext: Running in strict mode is one of those topics that comes back regularly but that never gets completly fixed because of more important topics. This bug is just here to remind us that and try to find a way to test this strict mode. The first step could be to have a tool that reports the status of bundles when they are run in strict mode. The second step could be to have a test application that is being run in strict mode.
do we need to create tool or turn on the strict mode options in the build? That way you get compile errors.

I think it depends on which plugins we want to impose the strict mode. But with the current build structure it is an all or nothing switch for all the bundles included in the eclipse SDK as well as equinox,etc...
To me a separate tool (aka a PDEState) has the advantage of offering another tool that one can run to get report without running a full build.

We have talked about this many times. I thought the last dicision was we were going to enable warnings in the build of the SDK. But this will not catch errors where people are using Bundle-Activator ...PluginActivator from the compatibility plugin.

bug.short_desc: [j2ee properties] Cannot use project dependeny for dynamic web projects

long_desc.thetext:
I have a dynamic web project (A). I want to depend on a regular Java project (B). I tried using Project Properties -> Build Path -> Projects tab. If I add project B to the list of required projects, Eclipse compiles without a problem, but the classes within project B are not published along with project A.
I can use project properties -> J2EE Module Dependencies and select project B, but this changes project B into a dynamic web project. I get additional builders (org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.builder and org.eclipse.wst.validation.validationbuilder) and a few more natures. This is simply not true. Project B is a simple Java project that's not web related.
In addition, even when I use J2EE Module Dependency, if project B has a few jars it depends on, they're not deployed with it (even if they're checked in project B's Java Build Path/Order and Export tab (within the Project Properties). The only thing deployed is a jar called B.jar that includes all the classes in project B. This issue was reported under bug 130948 and was said to be fixed in M200603070318, but I still see it in WTP 1.5.
You should step up to the WTP 1.5.2 builds. These will be much more stable and will have many fixes for the use of dependencies and publishing.
It still adds natures and builders, though, right?
If you add a java project as a j2ee reference to a web project, it will add the jst.utility facet and modulecore nature. It will not make that java project a web project.
Is this the right way? To add a J2EE module which is actually a Java project? Just doesn't seem right...
You are not adding a j2ee module. You go to the web lib tab and add the project as a web library project. This will cause the java project to be packaged as a jar under web-inf/lib at publish.
I'm sorry, but I don't see any web lib tab. Where exactly is it located (in the project properties)?
Right click on web project, select properties, select J2EE Module Dependencies, then flip to web lib tab.
I don't have this tab. It's probably on WTP version > 1.5.0 (2006/06/09). I'll upgrade after we ship the version to QA (in a bit over a week).

bug.short_desc: Problem in the implementation of the support of JSR-045

long_desc.thetext:
Suppose we have the JSP file:
testSimpleTag.jsp:[<%@ page import="java.io.*" %> some string here]
The valid SMAP for this JSP is: SMAP JEE_jsp_testSimpleTag_24890350_1152694486531_1152694491765.java JSP *S JSP *F + 0 testSimpleTag.jsp testSimpleTag.jsp *L 1:38,0 *E
We use page directive before the String in order to be able to put a breakpoint on this line, otherwise eclipse offers to add a bookmark. The right behavior of the debugger should be when the jsp execution hits the breakpoint the IDE to stop on this line. However this does not happen. So the problem here is that although the SMAP is valid and a breakpoint is set on this single line of the JSP, when the JSP page is requested eclipse does not stop on this breakpoint.
